attributes.alt: Book cover for Clifford's Manners by Norman Bridwell. The cover shows Clifford the Big Red Dog wearing a suit and top hat while people dance.

elements.text: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Print Concepts; Alphabet Knowledge
Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Aa and Bb, engage children in a song about friends, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What good manners does Clifford have?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Encourage children to identify the sounds /a/ and /b/.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Does your book have friends? Tell me about them.
Pretend you are at a restaurant. How can you use good manners?
How can you use manners to work on a puzzle with a friend?
What can you draw and write about your friend?
What can you make to give to a friend to say “thank you”? What materials will you choose?
How can you use the modeling clay to make the letters
you saw on the Alphabet Cards?
How can you use your manners to share the blocks with a friend? What can you say?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Demonstrate Empathy Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about when Clifford shows empathy.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Encourage children to create happy flowers.
Talk about when and why they might give someone a happy flower.
How can we be a good friend to others?
If you and a friend want to read the same book, can you show me a good way to solve the problem?
Pretend you want to play a game, but your friend doesn’t want to. How can you fix the problem?
Can you sort the pattern blocks with a friend?
Can you use stamps and stickers to write your friend’s name on a friendship card?
Can you make a friendship necklace? Why did you choose to use those materials?
Can you find the first letter of your name and the first letter of a friend’s name?
What can you and a friend build together with the blocks?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
When does Clifford use good manners?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Walk children through the voting process.
Guide children’s understanding of the value of the voting process.
Count votes with children to determine the most-chosen activity.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Can you find examples of good and bad manners in a book?
Pretend you and a friend are going to the park. What will you do there?
How many different ways can you sort the connecting cubes? Show me and count the ways.
What would you say in an email to a friend you miss? Can you draw and write about it?
How can you make a class voting box for when we take votes? What will you use?
How can you write letters in the shaving cream? Can you make
? Can you make the first letter of your name?
How can you build a doghouse for Clifford?

attributes.alt:
A chart with the title Thank You, Friend, showing three images of friends together and an email.
Images include:
•   Two boys dressed in similar hero costumes. The caption reads: Good friends like to do things together.
•   Two children smiling together. The caption reads: Good friends share and take turns.
•   Two girls sitting at a desk playing with blocks. The caption reads: Good friends do nice things for each other.
•   The email reads:
To: rico at mail dot com.
Subject: Thank you!
Dear Rico, Thank you for being a good friend to me. I like when we play superheroes. I think it’s nice when you take turns with me on the swings. You are so good at doing puzzles! I like when we read books together. I’m glad we are friends. From, Alisha.
Book cover for Clifford's Manners by Norman Bridwell. The cover shows Clifford the Big Red Dog wearing a suit and top hat while people dance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about being a good friend, use friendly introductions, and introduce vocabulary
Read interactively and connect to the Concept Question,
How can we be a good friend to others?
Select books and other texts for pre-reading.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Chart Paper, Colored Paper,  Art Supplies
Guide children to make thank-you notes.
Talk about different ways to be a good friend.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Can you find two books about being a friend? Which one do you like better? Why?
What could you say to a friend when you first see each other?
Can you use connecting cubes to make three different lengths? Which is shortest? longest?
Why would you send someone a thank-you note? What would you write on it?
Do you think you can make a mask that you can use when you play dress-up with a friend?
Can you write the first letter of your name in the sand tray?
Can you put the cars in order from smallest to largest?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Clifford's Manners by Norman Bridwell. The cover shows Clifford the Big Red Dog wearing a suit and top hat while people dance.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children sing and dance as they share ways classmates are good friends and to review vocabulary.
Begin story time by revisiting the book and asking,
How do you show you have good manners?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Why do you want to be a good friend to others?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we be a good friend to others?
Choose a book about friends. Can you find words that begin with Aa or Bb?
Choose two dolls and pretend they are friends at a park. What do they say to each other?
Can you use the counters to figure out how many friends are in our class?
Can you write to tell a friend why you like playing together?
Can you create a drawing of you and a friend playing?
Look at the Alphabet Cards for
. Can you write the letters on paper?
Can you create a playground out of blocks? Can you pretend the plastic people are playing there? How do they use manners?
